To examine the influence of Fe-Mn interactions on the catalytic removal to toluene, FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x catalysts were manufactured via co-precipitation approach. FeMnO x catalysts presented the optimal low-temperature catalytic toluene activity which attained 100 % removal of toluene (T100) at 270 ℃. The physical and chemical characterization of the material confirmed an increased ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olat bonds caused by to the formation of Fe3+-O-Mn3+ bonds. Concurrently, the low-temperature catalytic activity for toluene increased with the increased density of oxygen vacancies, the changed properties in oxygen vacancies and the enhanced oxidation capacity of surface activated oxygen species. In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed to infer different toluene degradation pathways on three catalysts. The catalytic routes for toluene over FeMnO x catalyst was different at 150 ℃ and 260 ℃. At 150 ℃, as the surface oxygen vacancies were not fully activated, the reaction pathway was toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → phenol. The path of toluene over FeMnO x catalyst at 260 ℃ was toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzoaldehyde → benzoate → maleic anhydride and carbonate → H2O and CO2. As compared with MnO x and FeO x catalysts, FeMnO x catalyst could oxidize benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde and phenol at 150 ℃. This decreased the energy required to open the ring of benzene and accelerated the catalytic oxidation rate. Graphical abstract FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x catalysts were prepared by co-precipitation method and the high-velocity active sites and catalytic mechanism on FeMnO x catalysts were investigated. The degradation pathway of toluene oxidation on the FeMnO x was speculated: toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid → maleic anhydride → CO2 and H2O. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Fe-Mn interaction Surface activated oxygen In situ DRIFTS Reaction mechanisms Data availability Data will be made available on request. Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) were mainly emitted to the atmosphere through vehicle exhaust and architectural coatings [1–3]. VOCs had been identified as a significant contributor to atmospheric concerns, such as photochemical smog, haze and global warming [4–6]. Several technologies, such as non-thermal plasma, chemical uptake, catalytic oxygenation, photocatalysis and adsorption, had been applied in the elimination of VOCs [7–10]. Catalytic oxidation was regarded as a potent VOCs treatment measure because of its lower reaction temperature, low costs and no secondary pollutants [11–14]. Noble metal catalysts possessed the excellent low-temperature catalytic activity by the high-velocity reaction sites (precious metal single atoms and clusters or oxygen vacancy), but their prohibitive cost and inferior stability limited practical industrial applications. In comparison, transition metal catalysts (Fe, Co, Cu, Mo, Ce, Mn, etc.) were affordable for practical applications. However, the low-temperature performance of transition metal catalysts still had potential to be improved because of the less amount of high-velocity reaction sites [15,16]. As a typical transition metal catalyst, the VOCs catalytic efficiency of manganese oxide catalysts had been demonstrated. The catalytic efficiency for VOCs was determined by the content of high-velocity reaction site (oxygen vacancy) in manganese oxide catalysts, which was closely related to the amount of Mn3+. Kim et al. provided that the toluene catalytic activity of the MnO x catalyst was Mn3O4 > Mn2O3 > MnO2, confirming the catalytic performance was affected by the chemical valence state of Mn species [17]. Zhang et al. indicated that the high activity of Mn2O3 was derived from the high concentration of oxygen vacancies and the lower Mn-O bond strength [18]. Zeng et al. demonstrated that the increased Mn3+ content would weaken the strength of the Mn-O bond and improved the oxygen mobility, which would enhance the catalytic activity [19]. For manganese oxide catalysts, it could be seen that the diminution of Mn-O bond strength was the key to enhance the high-velocity reaction site activity. However, due to the limitation of the MnO x crystal structure, there existed a range for the strength of the Mn-O bond and the concentration of oxygen vacancies. Fortunately, defects could be created through metal-to-metal interactions, which could further weaken Metal-O by forming a solid solution. The significance of defects was the activation of surface oxygen species and formation of surface active sites, which increased the reaction rate and improved the removal of VOCs [4,6,16,20,21]. As two adjacent transition metal elements, Fe and Mn exhibited similar atomic radii and chemical valence, which made solid solution easier to form. For Fe-Mn catalysts, the low temperature catalytic activity was affected by many factors. Chen et al. confirmed that the Mn-Fe catalysts prepared by hydrolysis driving redox reaction showed excellent catalytic oxidation activity of toluene due to the significant amount of oxygen vacancies which generated by Mn3+and the homogeneous distribution of lattice oxygen and metal sites [16]. Wang et al. covered the fabulous toluene catalytic oxidation activity with Fe3+ substituted Mn4+ in the MnO2 lattice, and the reason was due to the oxygen vacancies created by lattice substitution [4]. The study by Ma et al. showed that Fe-Mn catalysts prepared by impregnation was based on Fe as the main active component, and the high dispersion of this mixed oxide effectively improved the catalyst activity [20]. Soltan et al. validated that more oxygen vacancies and surface Oads appeared under the influence of Mn4+in Fe-Mn catalysts, which decreased the accumulation of intermediates (phenol) and improved the low-temperature catalytic activity [1]. Apparently, the high-velocity reaction sites and reaction paths of Fe-Mn catalysts were uncertain. Therefore, it was important to investigate and supplement the reactive sites and reaction mechanism of Fe-Mn catalysts. In this work, FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x were prepared by co-precipitation method, the mechanism for catalytic toluene was also explored. The crystal structure characteristics as well as various chemical properties of FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x samples were investigated by XRD, Raman, XPS, In situ DRIFTS, N2 isothermal adsorption-desorption and H2-TPR characterization. The interaction between Fe and Mn could influence the physical and chemical properties in FeMnO x catalyst, such as the formation of FeMnO x crystal-free structure, more active sites for oxygen adsorption and superior low-temperature oxidation–reduction ability. Two different reaction paths were proposed to highlight the effect of elemental Fe and Mn interactions on the overall toluene low-temperature catalytic activity and the stability, which served as a guide for practical industrial production. Experimental Materials and chemicals The purity of the reagents used in the experiment was Analytical Reagent and was not further purified. Fe(NO3)3·9H2O was used as Fe sources and Mn(NO3)2 (50 wt. % solutions) was used as Mn sources, respectively. Ammonia solution was applied to change the pH in the aqueous solution which the iron and manganese sources had been dissolved to produce the iron-manganese complexes. Catalyst preparation A co-precipitation method was chosen as the catalyst preparation method. 35.8 mmol of Fe(NO3)3 as well as 36.4 mmol of Mn(NO3)2 were first dissolved in ultrapure water at 25 ℃. Then gradually add ammonia to the clarified solution. When the pH value reached 10 and remained stable, the vessel was placed in a water bath at 80 ℃ and kept stirring for 4 h, washed with ultrapure water until the precipitation was neutral and then filtered. The precipitate obtained by filtration was placed in oven at 105 ℃ to ensure drying, then placed in a muffle furnace at 550 ℃ and roasted for 2 h. The preparation steps for FeO x catalyst and MnO x catalyst were the same. Catalytic activity evaluation The experiments for the testing of catalytic activity to toluene were conducted on a stationary bed reflector in an atmospheric pressure. 0.15 mL of catalyst with 40–60 mesh diameter was placed on quartz wool in a glass tube. The gas mixture of 1000 ppm of toluene, O2 and N2 was introduced at a throughput of 66.7 mL·min−1. The density of toluene after the reaction was measured by FULI 9790 equipped with FID detectors. The catalytic oxidation experiments on toluene were started in the range from 70 ℃ to 310 ℃. The removal of toluene was calculated by Eqs. (1): (1) Toluene removal = [ T ] in − [ T ] out [ T ] in × 100 % In the equation, the [T]in denote the entrance density of toluene and [T]out showed the outlet density of toluene. Before performing activity tests on the catalyst, it was essential to first establish that the movement of the gas phase between the pores of the catalyst was stable. A combination of 8 mm diameter quartz wool and glass tubes was selected as the catalyst placement area. Heat the glass tube as a whole until the temperature reached 70 ℃. The toluene density of experimental exhaust gaseous substance was measured by gaseous substance chromatograph as an evaluation criterion for the stability of the gas flow rate. The gas flow rate of the reactor was considered to be stable when the difference in toluene concentration in three consecutive exhaust gasses did not exceed 20 ppm, and then a test of catalyst activity was performed. Catalyst characterizations XRD result was obtained on the Ultima IV/Bruker D8 ADVANCE diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ=1.5406 Å). The angle of 2θ took a range from 10° to 72° and the scanning rate was 8°/min. The N2 adsorption-desorption result was calculated by SSA-6000 specific surface area analyzers at −196 ℃. Based on this data the pore size distribution of the three samples were calculated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) result was acquired by the ESCALab 250Xi instrumentation which used Al Ka as the excitation source. Raman spectra was collected by a RENISHAW Raman microscpe which was installed a CCD detector. The testing range was programmed from 100 cm−1 to 2000 cm−1. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on the PCA-1200 instrument. In situ DRIFTS were obtained on the Nicolet IS 10 FT-IR spectrometer connected to a MCT demodulator. Results and discussion Characterization of material physics structure The XRD patterns of FeMnO x catalysts and their respective catalysts were placed in Fig. 1 . Among them, the diffraction peaks appearing at 2θ angles of 18.0°, 28.9°, 31.1°, 32.5°, 36.2°, 38.0°, 44.6°, 50.9°, 53.9°, 56.0°, 58.8°, 60.0°, 64.7° for Mn catalysts belonged to (101), (112), (200), (103), (211), (004), (220), (105), (312), (303), (321), (224) and (116) crystal interface of Mn3O4 by compared with standard cards (PDF#01-1127) [22,23]. The peak shape corresponded to (211) crystal plane was the sharpest, which indicated that the crystallinity of Mn3O4 was favorable and the main exposed crystal plane was (211) crystal plane, which was consistent with the situation reflected in the standard card. Meanwhile, the broad diffraction peak at 32.9° was attributed to (222) crystalline surface of Mn2O3 (PDF#41-1442) [24]. This demonstrated the presence of crystals of Mn2O3 as well as Mn3O4 on the surface of MnO x . For the FeO x catalysts, the peaks at 24.1°, 33.1°, 35.6°, 40.8°, 49.4°, 54.0°, 57.6°, 62.5° and 64.0° all correlated with the standard peaks of α-Fe2O3 crystals (PDF # 24-0072) [25,26]. The characteristic peaks at different angles were sharp and high, which indicated that the FeO x catalysts contained a large number of α-Fe2O3 crystals with high crystallinity. For the FeMnO x catalysts, no obvious characteristic peaks were found in XRD, which indicated that the FeMnO x catalyst forms an amorphous structure and might be existed in the form of Fe-Mn solid solution. This amorphous structure was probably caused by the interaction between the transition metals of Fe and Mn. Since Fe and Mn had similar atomic radii and elemental valence, they were more susceptible to lattice substitution, which led to lattice distortion [4]. Catalysts with excellent crystallinity possessed less oxygen vacancy content and less active oxygen capture sites, which could lead to inferior low-temperature activity of the catalyst [6]. Weak crystallinity on the surface of FeMnO x catalysts was detected, which caused the generation of a large number of defective sites and a significant increase in the content of active oxygen trapping sites and oxygen vacancies [27]. The peak of the MnO x catalyst at 655 cm−1 in the Raman spectrum of Fig. 2 represented the vibration of Mn-O bond in Mn3O4 crystal structure [28,29]. The peaks at 226 cm−1, 245 cm−1, 293 cm−1, 408 cm−1 and 1320 cm−1 were all typically characteristic peaks of α-Fe2O3 for FeO x catalysts [30,31]. For the FeMnO x catalyst, the characteristic peak of Mn-O bond was blue-shifted, which meant that the bond energy was changed due to the effect of Fe element [28]. To visualize the modification of the bond energy of Mn-O bond more clearly, the bonding force constant k was obtained from Hooke's law (Eqs. 2) [32]: (2) ω = 1 2 π c k μ where ω was the Raman shift of Mn-O stretching vibration, c was the speed of light, μ was the effective mass of the Mn-O bond. Bonding constants showed that MnO x > FeMnO x . According to previous studies, a lower bonding constant represented a weaker Mn-O bond energy, which resulted to a higher oxygen mobility as well as yielding preferable activity [33]. Meanwhile, characteristic peaks attributed to α-Fe2O3 appeared on the surface of FeMnO x , indicating the uniform distribution of Fe and Mn elements on the surface of FeMnO x catalyst. This excellent dispersion facilitated the oxidation for toluene [33]. The catalyst specific surface area was explored via performing BET experiments on the catalyst. Generally speaking, a higher specific surface area meant that more crystalline surfaces were exposed and more contact area with the reactants, which led to a greater probability of the reaction occurring or being accelerated. From Fig. 3 (a), it was observed that the adsorption curves of all catalysts belonged to type Ⅳ isotherms and H3 hysteresis loops, which proved that all these samples were mesoporous materials. The existence of mesopores (Fig. 3(b)) was also confirmed by the pore size distribution of the sample which was calculated by Barrett Joyner Halenda (BJH) [34,35]. When the average pore size was chosen as the evaluation criterion, the FeMnO x catalyst showed the smallest average pore size. Catalysts with mesoporous structures were significant for the catalytic oxidation of VOCs. The mesoporous structure extended the range of molecular sizes in which the gas reacted within the pore and the active center presented a better accessibility [33]. From the results of BET (Table 1 ), it could be concluded that FeMnO x catalyst possessed the highest specific surface area. This meant that the FeMnO x catalyst had a greater potential to bring toluene into contact with the catalytic active site and trigger the reaction. Chemical properties of catalysts XPS was performed for the qualitative and quantitative analysis of elemental valence states on the catalyst. The states of Fe, Mn and O in different catalysts and the corresponding binding energies were shown in Fig. 4 , respectively. For elemental Fe, the binding energy (BE) of Fe3+ 2p3/2 orbital was 712.1 eV in FeO x catalysts. However, in FeMnO x catalyst, the BE of Fe3+ 2p3/2 orbital was 711.6 eV [6]. Due to the fact that Fe possessed a stronger electronegativity than Mn, the electron density of the Fe was increased when Fe-Mn interacted, which weakened the shielding effect of the outer electrons in Fe. This could be the reason for the decreased BE of Fe3+. Meanwhile, the Fe of FeMnO x was more present in the form of Fe3+. Compared with FeO x catalyst (Table 2 ), FeMnO x catalyst exhibited a larger Fe3+/(Fe2++Fe3+). This could be due to the strong Fe-Mn interaction which resulted in the conversion of some Fe2+ to Fe3+. The state about the manganese element was placed in Fig. 4(b). Mn 2p3/2 strips were selected for fitting, and Mn3+/Mn4+ was evaluated by calculating the peak areas of the Mn3+ and Mn4+ characteristic peaks [32]. The peaks located near 640.9 eV, 642.1 eV and 643.6 eV were defined as Mn2+, Mn3+ and Mn4+, respectively [16,36]. In MnO x catalysts, the element Mn was mostly presented on the catalyst as Mn4+ valence. The comparison with the FeMnO x catalyst showed that Mn3+ was more presented on the surface of the catalyst due to the influence of Fe element. The phenomenon might arise from the fact that the Fe2+-O-Mn4+ bond experienced an electron transfer, which created the Fe3+-O-Mn3+ bond. It was known from previous studies that more Mn3+ led to more defective sites, which accelerated the catalytic reaction [32]. The reason could be attributed to the fact that the weak bond energy of Mn3+-O. When toluene was adsorbed on the Mn3+ atom, the O attached to Mn3+ was more likely to react with the toluene molecule. At the same time, the BE of the Mn element in the FeMnO x catalyst was shifted to a higher direction, which implied a decrease in the valence electron density. This confirmed the formation of Fe3+-O-Mn3+ covalent bond. The same point could be demonstrated by the change of BE of Fe3+ on FeO x catalyst and FeMnO x catalyst. The oxygen species on the catalyst could be determined by the O binding energy. Where the peak located at 529.5 eV corresponded to the surface lattice oxygen (Olat) [37]. The oxygen species located near 530.5 eV were adsorbed reactive oxygen species (Oads) [38]. From Fig. 4(c), the following order was obtained by fitting the content of different oxygen species for the three catalysts: FeO x > MnO x > FeMnOx for Olat and FeMnO x > MnO x > FeO x for Oads. The higher the concentration of oxygen vacancies was formed, the more easily the gas-phase O2 was activated by the catalyst, thus forming more surface-active adsorbed oxygen, Oads played a major part in deep oxidation of toluene [39]. And the high presence of Mn3+ corresponded to the density of oxygen vacancies at surface of catalyst [28,40,41]. The results showed that the FeMnO x catalyst possessed the highest surface activity of adsorbed oxygen (29.5) and the highest Mn3+ content (40.7), which might accelerate its catalytic oxidation of toluene (Table 2). To summarize, in the FeMnO x catalyst, Mn4+ and Fe2+ were converted to Mn3+ and Fe3+ due to the strong interaction between elemental Fe and Mn. It was worth emphasizing that the BE of the O element in the FeMnO x catalyst shifted to a lower direction, which was related to the debilitating in the covalent bond (M-O bond) caused by the interaction between the metal elements, which was also consistent with Raman results. With the aim of investigating the effect of redox ability on the catalytic oxidation to toluene, we performed H2-TPR (Fig. 5 ). The reduction peak appearing before 200 ℃ was considered to be the reduction of surface activated oxygen species [39,42]. The first reduction peak appeared in the MnO x catalyst, and the reduction peak at 303 ℃ was considered as MnO2 to Mn2O3 conversion. At 440 ℃, which was thought to be the reduction of Mn2O3 to Mn3O4/MnO, the second reduction peak was located [43,44]. The Mn4+ on the surface of MnO x catalysts was abundant and uniformly dispersed, resulting in the lowest reduction temperature. For the FeO x catalysts, the reduction peak of Fe3+ was reduced to Fe2+, which was considered to be located at 394 ℃. The subsequent reduction peak at 622 ℃ was considered to be the reduction of Fe3O4 to FeO, and the reduction peak after 700 ℃ should belong to the reduction of FeO to Fe [45,46]. Interestingly, for the FeMnO x catalyst, the first reduction peak at 310 ℃ was higher than the reduction peak of Mn4+ and lower than the reduction peak of Fe3+. This meant that the reduction peaks at 310 ℃ belonged to Mn4+ and Fe3+. Owing to the mutual effect of elemental Fe and Mn, the redox ability of Mn4+ was reduced and that of Fe3+ was increased. The combined reduction of Fe3+ and Mn4+ led to an increase in the reduction temperature. The peak at 430 ℃ was considered to be the reduction peak of Mn3+ and Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, and the reduction peak at 473 ℃ was Fe3+ to Fe2+ (Fe3O4 to FeO). The better redox ability could promote the catalytic activity of the catalyst [ 47 , 48 ]. FeMnO x catalysts provided the highest amount of surface oxygen vacancies and favorable redox capabilities. This facilitated the catalytic oxidation process of toluene. Catalytic activity Fig. 6 (a) displayed the catalytic removal of FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x for toluene. The temperature at the 50 % removal of toluene (T50) and the temperature at the 100 % removal of toluene (T100) were used as the basis for evaluating the catalyst activity. The results showed that the T50 (251 ℃) and T100 (270 ℃) of FeMnO x were the lowest, which evidenced the catalytic removal of FeMnO x samples were the highest for toluene. Meanwhile, the T50 and T100 of MnO x were 270 ℃ and 300 ℃, respectively. The toluene catalytic removal of FeO x at 200–300 ℃ was not obvious, and the removal rate of 50 % for toluene was still not achieved at 300 ℃. Compared to the catalytic effect of toluene with Mn catalyst, the FeMnO x catalyst showed significantly higher activity. From the catalytic activity diagram, it could be guessed that the increased removal of FeMnO x catalysts compared to MnO x catalysts was due to the doping of Fe. The Fe doping caused more oxygen vacancies and more adsorbed oxygen on the FeMnO x catalysts, which facilitated the stepwise oxidation process of toluene. The stability of FeMnO x catalysts were tested at 255 ℃ and 250 ℃. The performances were shown in Fig 6(b), and the removal rate of toluene by FeMnO x catalyst was maintained at 80 % (255 ℃) and 50 % (250 ℃) for 36 h, individually. There was a slight decrease in toluene removal at 250 ℃ after 30 h. This could be due to the low reaction rate of the active sites, which resulted in the production of carbon buildup and thus deactivation of the active sites. Thereby, FeMnO x catalyst exhibited the excellent resistance to carbon deposition when it was involved in the catalytic removal of toluene. In situ drifts research To investigate the differences in catalytic mechanisms between FeO x and MnO x and FeMnO x catalysts for toluene, we performed in situ DRIFTS at different temperatures. Fig. 7 (a) and (b) showed that the FeO x catalyst exhibited an increasing peak height of the vibration from the aromatic ring peak (1593 cm−1 [49], 1326 cm−1 [50], 3073 cm−1 [3]) and symmetric and asymmetric CH stretching vibrations of benzyl and the aromatic ring of toluene peak (2937 cm−1, 3039 cm−1 [3,51]) along with the increasing of adsorption time at both 150 ℃ and 260 ℃. The difference was the presence of Phenyl-C-O (Ph-C-O) species on the FeO x catalyst at low temperatures, as could be demonstrated by the vibration of CO on the C atom attached to the benzene ring peak at 1265 cm−1 [2,52] and CO vibration mode peak at 1149 cm−1 [49]. At high temperature, the peak intensity at 1593 cm−1 was dramatically increased with time, indicating that the toluene adsorption was significantly increased. This might be attributed to the high temperature activated more active sites. The characteristic peaks located at 1271 cm−1 [52], 1324 cm−1 [52] and 1413 cm−1 [3] were represented individually by stretching vibration of the CO group benzyl alcohol and the subsequent intermediates generated by benzyl alcohol oxidation, COO- asymmetry as well as symmetry vibrations of benzoate. Based on the above results, it could be assumed that benzyl alcohol and benzoic acid without ring opening were accumulating on the surface of FeO x catalyst at 260 ℃, causing that further deep oxidation was difficult to occur, which resulted in the inferior catalytic performance over FeO x . For the MnO x catalyst (Fig. 7(c) and (d)), the characteristic peaks of skeleton vibrations of the typical aromatic ring v (CC) (1595 cm−1 and 1592 cm−1) and symmetric and asymmetric CH- stretching vibrations of benzyl (3042 cm−1 and 3045 cm−1) observed at 150 ℃ and 260 ℃ [3,49,51]. The intensity of the peak at 3042 cm−1 at 150 ℃ decreased with the increase of the adsorption time, and the peaks at 1270 cm−1 and 1280 cm−1, which represented the stretching vibration of the CO group the infrared signal of benzyl alcohol and benzoic acid and benzyl alcohol species, respectively, also showed a decrease in intensity [6,52]. This indicated that the benzyl alcohol species was first produced when toluene was adsorbed on the surface of the MnO x catalyst, which could be obtained by COH stretching vibration of alcohols peak at 1037 cm−1 [27]. As time increased, benzyl alcohol was converted to benzoic acid, which could be confirmed by the characteristic peaks that represented asymmetric vibration of the COO- of the benzoate species at 1405 cm−1 and 1528 cm−1 where the peak intensity increased with time [1,2,6]. This phenomenon appeared on the surface of the MnO x catalyst at 260 ℃. The differences were that the acidic anhydride species peak and the bicarbonate species peak appeared at 1301 cm−1 and 1446 cm−1, respectively [1,6,49]. It could be proved that the cleavage of benzene ring occurred on the MnO x catalyst at high temperature, but the peak intensity of 3045 cm−1 characteristic peak that represented the benzene ring increased with time, which indicated that the cleavage and adsorption of the benzene ring on the catalyst did not reach the equilibrium. The catalytic pathway of toluene over MnO x catalyst was as follows toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzoic acid → acid anhydride, Bicarbonate → CO2 and H2O. The possible reaction pathways on FeMnO x catalysts were inferred by means of detecting intermediates in the catalytic process. In situ DRIFTS of the catalytic removal to toluene by FeMnO x catalyst at 150 ℃ were placed in Fig. 7(e). The peak located at 1509 cm−1 was CC vibration bands of benzene [6,53]. The peak located at 1047 cm−1 was defined as benzyloxy group, which meant that toluene reacted chemically with the reactive oxygen species on the FeMnO x catalyst [3]. The appearance of this characteristic peak proved that toluene was adsorbed on the surface of FeMnO x catalyst. The strong peak at 1266 cm−1 was thought to belong to the vibration of CO on the C atom attached to the benzene ring [2,52]. The characteristic peaks 1647 cm−1 and 1439 cm−1 representing benzaldehyde species increased continuously with time [4,5]. The peak positioned at 1344 cm−1 was identified as the vs (COO−) of carboxylate, corresponding to benzoic acid species [54,55]. The characteristic peak located at 1246 cm−1 was determined as stretching vibration of the CO bond, which implied the formation of phenol [39]. Based on the above results and previous works, it could be deduced that the reaction pathway of toluene over FeMnO x catalyst at 150 ℃. First, toluene was physically adsorbed on the catalyst due to the mesoporous structure of the catalyst, with the activation of the adsorbed oxygen species, the methyl group on toluene linked with the adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst to produce benzyl alcohol species, and as it continued to accumulate on the catalyst surface. Subsequently oxidized to benzaldehyde and benzoic acid by reactive oxygen species on oxygen vacancies. Since the temperature was low, benzoic acid could only be further oxidized to phenol and could not cleave the benzene ring [54,55]. The in situ DRIFTS profile of the surface variety of species of the FeMnO x catalyst at 260 ℃ was located in Fig. 7(f). Two faint peaks appeared at 1020 cm−1 and 1175 cm−1, and no change in peak intensity with increasing of time, and they were consistent with the stretching vibration characteristics of CO bonds of alkoxide species [2,6]. The position of the peak that has not changed in intensity with time was likewise at 3065 cm−1, which was the peak characteristic of the vibration of the CH bond on the aromatic ring [56]. These phenomena indicated that the accumulation of primary products of toluene catalytic oxidation did not occur due to the high oxidation efficiency of the active sites in FeMnO x sample at high temperatures. The dominant species located at 1403 cm−1, 1585 cm−1 and 1528 cm−1 was considered to be the asymmetric vibration of the COO- of the benzoate or carboxylate species [1,2,6]. The characteristic peak appearing at 1447 cm−1 was considered to be a bicarbonate species (HCO-) [49]. The 1305 cm−1 band was identified as an acidic anhydride species, indicating the formation of maleic anhydride [1,6]. According to the above results, it could be concluded that the fragmentation of toluene benzene ring occurred on the catalyst at 260 ℃. This reaction produced carboxylate and bicarbonate which would be further decomposed into H2O and CO2. The benzaldehyde and phenol species that accumulate in large quantities on the catalyst surface at low temperatures did not materialize on the catalyst surface at 260 ℃. This might be due to the fast conversion rate of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid at elevated temperatures, which led to the inability of benzaldehyde and phenol to aggregate on the catalyst surface [6]. Based on the previous work and the results of in situ DRIFTS, two different catalytic oxidation reaction pathways of toluene on the FeMnO x catalyst platform could be hypothesized. At 150 ℃, toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → phenol. At 260 ℃, toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzoaldehyde → benzoic acid → maleic anhydride, carbonate → H2O, CO2 [1,6,27]. The direct oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzoic acid required high activation energy, while the reaction from benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde first demanded less activation energy, so the conversion benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid required less activation energy and more rapid reaction. The conclusion of in situ DRIFTS indicated the mechanism of toluene removal on FeMnO x catalyst was different with MnO x and FeO x catalyst. For FeMnO x catalysts, at low temperatures, the oxygen vacancies were not completely activated and toluene was first adsorbed by the catalyst, then oxidized to benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde species by the active adsorbed oxygen, and subsequently oxidized to phenol by O (oxygen vacancy) of Mn3+-O-Fe3+ bond that was not completely activated. At 260 ℃, toluene was first reacted with surface adsorbed oxygen to produce benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde, followed by oxidation by O (oxygen vacancy) of Mn3+-O-Fe3+ bond to benzoic acid species and produced maleic acid by ring opening, and finally by complete oxidation to H2O and CO2. However, the oxidation capacity of the surface adsorbed oxygen of the MnO x catalyst was insufficient, resulting in the adsorption of toluene to the catalyst surface only to produce benzyl alcohol, which was converted to benzoic acid by deep oxidation of surface active oxygen, followed by ring opening to produce maleic acid species, and finally oxidized to CO2 and H2O. The least toluene removal FeO x catalyst presented a more struggling catalytic oxidation of toluene due to the less active adsorbed oxygen and less oxygen vacancy concentration caused by the excellent crystalline state. It could be seen that the oxidation capacity of the active adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst and the oxygen vacancy concentration were the main reasons affecting the reaction pathway and activity of the catalyst. Discussion In this study, FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x samples were manufactured via co-precipitation method, their catalytic activities for toluene were investigated. The results of XRD, BET, Raman, XPS and H2-TPR showed that the formation of Fe3+-O-Mn3+ bond caused the change of the properties in the catalyst, including oxygen species, redox properties, oxygen vacancies and specific surface area. These were significant to the improvement of the low temperature catalytic performance for toluene. These changes in properties resulted in the improved catalytic performance at low temperatures for toluene. Qin et al. reported that non-crystalline Fe and Mn enhanced the catalytic activity towards toluene [57]. According to the results of Fig. 1, the Fe-Mn amorphous solid solution structure was formed in the FeMnO x catalyst. The formation of the amorphous structure was attributed to Fe-Mn interactions, which was the formation of Fe3+-O-Mn3+ bonds. The specific surface area of FeMnO x catalyst increased significantly. A higher specific surface area generally corresponded to a well-dispersed and effective catalytic activity [58]. Due to the stronger electronegativity of Fe, the electron cloud was shifted toward the element Fe when the Fe3+-O-Mn3+ bond was formed. This conclusion could be proved by the change of binding energy of Fe and Mn elements in XPS results. The shift in the electron cloud could weaken the strength of the Mn-O bond as well as enhanced the bond length of Mn-O. This meant that when the Mn element was used as an adsorption site for toluene, the O attached to the Mn atom was more likely to react with toluene, thus formed a high-speed reaction site. The variation of Mn-O bond strength in Raman results proved this conclusion. It was known that oxygen vacancies were one of the important factors that affected the catalyst activity. In general, the oxygen species on the oxygen vacancy was Oads [59,60]. The highest ratio of Oads/(Oads+Olat) on FeMnO x catalyst could be seen by the results of XPS and H2-TPR. The interaction between Fe and Mn resulted in the formation of more Mn3+ on the FeMnO x catalyst. In Mn-based catalysts, more amounts of Mn3+ meant that more oxygen vacancies were formed [61]. This meant easier redox reactions of surface oxygen on Fe3+-O-Mn3+ oxygen vacancies. Wang et al. studied that the formation of oxygen vacancies VO(FM) due to Fe and Mn interactions was the key to improve the catalytic efficiency of toluene [4]. This active site was also confirmed to exist in our study by the results of H2-TPR and XPS. According to the MVK mechanism, toluene was oxidized to CO2 and H2O by the oxygen species on the catalyst surface first, and at the same time formed oxygen vacancies on the catalyst, and then the oxygen vacancies were re-oxidized by the oxygen species in the gas phase, which formed a complete cycle process. Therefore, more oxygen vacancies meant more active sites on the catalyst surface. Oads/(Oads+Olat) could reflect the presence of oxygen vacancies. In combination with Fig. 8 , it could be concluded that the FeMnO x catalyst formed an amorphous structure, which generated a larger specific surface area and more oxygen vacancies, and formed an active site with better redox ability, leading to an increase in the low-temperature catalytic efficiency of toluene. Table 3 showed a comparison of the degradation temperatures of relevant samples reported in the literature with typical samples obtained in the present work [62–64]. It was obvious that the FeMnO x catalyst prepared possessed better catalytic activity. Conclusion In this investigation, FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x catalysts were synthesized by co-precipitation method. The catalytic performance and reaction mechanism of their catalytic of toluene removal were examined. Due to the strong interaction of Fe and Mn, the FeMnO x catalyst formed a solid solution structure, resulting in the largest specific surface area and the excellent dispersion of Fe and Mn, which provided the maximum contact area for toluene adsorption. Furthermore, the high-velocity reaction sites (defect sites and oxygen vacancies) were formed by Fe2++Mn4+→Fe3++Mn3+, which contributed to the generation of activated oxygen and the increase of electron transfer rate, causing the excellent catalytic performance over FeMnO x . Besides, FeMnO x catalysts exhibited the lowest peak initiation temperature and the highest amount of surface active oxygen species, which could improve the catalytic ability. In situ DRIFTs results showed that Fe3+-O-Mn3+ was not totally activated at low temperature and the degradation pathway was benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → phenol, and at 260 ℃ the degradation pathway was benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → benzoic acid → maleic acid → H2O and CO2. Our investigation refined the reaction pathway of FeMnO x catalysts and highlighted the strong interaction between metal elements for the activation of oxygen vacancies. coredata.dc:description: To examine the influence of Fe-Mn interactions on the catalytic removal to toluene, FeO x , MnO x and FeMnO x catalysts were manufactured via co-precipitation approach. FeMnO x catalysts presented the optimal low-temperature catalytic toluene activity which attained 100 % removal of toluene (T100) at 270 ℃. The physical and chemical characterization of the material confirmed an increased ratio of Mn3+/Mn4+ and Oads/Olat bonds caused by to the formation of Fe3+-O-Mn3+ bonds. Concurrently, the low-temperature catalytic activity for toluene increased with the increased density of oxygen vacancies, the changed properties in oxygen vacancies and the enhanced oxidation capacity of surface activated oxygen species. In situ DRIFTS experiments were performed to infer different toluene degradation pathways on three catalysts. The catalytic routes for toluene over FeMnO x catalyst was different at 150 ℃ and 260 ℃. At 150 ℃, as the surface oxygen vacancies were not fully activated, the reaction pathway was toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzaldehyde → phenol. The path of toluene over FeMnO x catalyst at 260 ℃ was toluene → benzyl alcohol → benzoaldehyde → benzoate → maleic anhydride and carbonate → H2O and CO2. As compared with MnO x and FeO x catalysts, FeMnO x catalyst could oxidize benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde and phenol at 150 ℃. This decreased the energy required to open the ring of benzene and accelerated the catalytic oxidation rate.
coredata.dc:title: An investigation of the activity and mechanism of the catalytic oxidation of toluene by FeMnO x catalyst
